briefOverview: Nephi introduces his selection of Isaiah’s writings, emphasizing multiple prophetic witnesses of Christ and the law of Moses as typifying Him.
summary: Nephi notes that Jacob taught many things, though he records only part of them. He declares his delight in Isaiah’s words and intends to apply (“liken”) them to his people, asserting that Isaiah, Nephi, and Jacob have all seen the Redeemer. By the “words of three” witnesses, Nephi aims to establish the truth of his testimony. He teaches that the law of Moses and all divine gifts from the beginning typify Christ, and he rejoices in the Lord’s covenants and in the plan of deliverance from death. Nephi insists that without Christ all would perish, and even creation would be null, but affirms that God is Christ and will come in the fulness of His time. He then introduces the forthcoming words of Isaiah, inviting readers to rejoice and apply them to all people.
externalContext: According to the Book of Mormon narrative, Nephi wrote in the 6th century BCE after his family departed Jerusalem around the time of Babylon’s rise. The Nephites preserved the law of Moses while looking forward to a future Messiah, and they possessed a record (the brass plates) containing extensive writings of Isaiah. In ancient Israelite law, establishing matters by multiple witnesses (two or three) was a common legal principle, shaping how claims were validated. Isaiah’s prophecies were central in Second Temple Judaism and early Christianity for understanding the Messiah and God’s redemptive purposes.
externalReferences: Nephi’s appeal to validation by multiple witnesses reflects Deuteronomy 19:15 (see also 2 Corinthians 13:1). His claim that the law of Moses was given to typify Christ aligns with New Testament reflections on the law as a tutor and a shadow pointing to Christ (Galatians 3:24; Hebrews 10:1). The statement that Isaiah “saw” the Redeemer echoes Isaiah’s throne vision (Isaiah 6:1) and relates to his messianic prophecies (Isaiah 7:14; 9:6; 53:3–5).

sectionTitles.title: Law typifies Christ and plan of deliverance

practicalQuestions: How can I intentionally “liken” Isaiah’s writings to my life and community today?
Which trustworthy witnesses (scriptural and personal) reinforce my faith in Christ, and how do I weigh them?
In what ways do my religious observances or traditions point me more clearly to Christ rather than distract from Him?
How do God’s covenants shape my hope regarding death and deliverance?
What practices help me read prophetic texts with joy, as Nephi models here?
uncertainAreas: The precise theological force of “if there be no Christ there be no God … he is Christ” within Nephi’s view of the Godhead is not fully explained; the scope of “all things … typifying” Christ is broad and somewhat undefined; and the nature of Isaiah’s and Jacob’s “seeing” the Redeemer (visionary vs. other forms of witness) is not specified.
